metadata.title: "Medicine for the Return of Wives"
metadata.author: Chester Pepper
metadata.publication: William Bright, The Karok Language (1957), pp. 254-257, Text 52

s.txt:
vaa
kun kúph aanik .
s.trans: They did this.

s.txt:
áxak
kun ifyúku ti
asiktávaan sa
kôokaninay .
s.trans: Two women wandered around everywhere.

s.txt:
kun máah ti
p eekxaréeyav
t u 'íifship .
s.trans: They would see where a spirit had grown up (i.e., was living).

s.txt:
vaa
tá
kun 'áhakuv .
s.trans: They would go there.

s.txt:
kóomahich
ník
kóovan
tá
kun 'áraarahi tih .
s.trans: They would stay with him a little while.

s.txt:
kári
kúkuum
tá
kun 'áhoo .
s.trans: Then they would travel again.

s.txt:
kúkuum
fátaak
tá
kun máh "
ikxaréeyav
t u 'íifship ."
s.trans: Again somewhere they would see that a spirit had grown up.

s.txt:
púyava
kóomahich
ník
kóovan
tá
kun 'áraarahi tih .
s.trans: So they would stay with him a little while.

s.txt:
chavúra
páy
p eethívthaaneen
thaanêen
kun piruvápiroopithva .
s.trans: Finally they went all around this world.

s.txt:
kári
xás
vaa
kâam
ifuchtîimich
kun ítvaavnuk
aseeshtákak .
s.trans: And finally, at aseeshtákak, they looked over, a little ways upriver.

s.txt:
sâam
kun itfáku tih .
s.trans: They looked downhill.

s.txt:
yánava
ikxaréeyav
t u 'íifship .
s.trans: They saw a spirit had grown up.

s.txt: ikmahachram'íshiip veekxaréeyav .
s.trans: It was Sacred Sweathouse Spirit.
s.note: This is the spirit who lived in the ikmahachram'íshiip, the sacred sweathouse of Katimin, used in the world-renewal ceremony.

s.txt:
xás
kun xus , "
chími
nu sôomkir ."
s.trans: And they thought, "Let's offer ourselves in marriage!"
s.note: Bright doesn't write the ending ", but that seems to be a mistake, so I've added it.

s.txt:
ta'ítam
kúuk
kun 'úum aheen .
s.trans: So they went there.

s.txt:
ta'ítam
mu 'iv'îikam
kun 'iru kûurishrih een .
s.trans: And they sat down outside his house.
s.note: Bright writes two accents on tá'ítam, but it is probably a typo so I wrote only the expected accent.

s.txt:
xás
u xú ti
ikmahachram'íshiip veekxaréeyav ,
u xús "
naa
vúra
naní 'iish
pu 'axvíthin heesh ara ."
s.trans: And Sacred Sweathouse Spirit thought, he thought, "My body will not become unclean."

s.txt:
uum
vúra
hitíhaan
vaa
kích
u kupi tih ,
ú kvaat ih .
s.trans: He did only this all the time, he gathered sweathouse wood.
s.note: Bright: "That is, the hero avoided sexual intercourse with the women, which would have been magically defiling, and devoted himself to gathering sweathouse wood, an activity of high ceremonial value."

s.txt:
imáan
ú kvaat ih .
s.trans: The next day (also) he gathered sweathouse wood.

s.txt:
ásxaay
u píychaak iri tih .
s.trans: He spoiled his luck with green wood.
s.note: Bright: "This is explained by a Karok maxim: peefmâarahaak xáyfaat ík asxay'áhup íyuunkirihtih, ayu'âach pamihrooha'îin i'iitshúreeshap 'When you marry, you mustn't put green wood in the fire, because your wife will leave you.'"

s.txt:
kári
xás
u xus , "
xâatik
tápas
ni kyáa vunaa ."
s.trans: And he thought, "Let me take care of them."

s.txt:
ta'ítam
u músan vunaa heen .
s.trans: So he went to see them.

s.txt:
ta'ítam
iinâak
u 'oonvá furuk .
s.trans: So he took them inside the living house.

s.txt:
kári
xás
vaa
kun kúupha ,
mukun íkriv
kun ikyâa heen .
s.trans: And they did this, they made their living.

s.txt:
kári
xás
vaa
u kúupha ,
ikmaháchraam
kúuk
u 'íipma .
s.trans: Then he did this, he went back to the sweathouse.

s.txt:
chavúra
teepshítaanivanihich
xás
pa mu krívraam
u p ímuus tih .
s.trans: Finally after a little while he looked at his living house.

s.txt:
púxay
vúra xay
amkúuf xay .
s.trans: There was no smoke.

s.txt:
xás
u xú ti "
hûut
áta
tá
kun kúupha ."
s.trans: And he thought, "I wonder what they're doing?"

s.txt:
xás
u xus , "
tîi
kan p imúsan vunaa ."
s.trans: And he thought, "Let me go to see them again!"

s.txt:
p oo tfúnuk va
yánava
vúra
púra fáat .
s.trans: When he looked into the living house, he saw there was nothing there.

s.txt:
xás
u xú ti "
húuk
áta
tá
kun 'uum ,
pa nini hrôoh as ."
s.trans: And he thought, "I wonder where my wives have gone?"

s.txt:
xás
u xús "
miník
ni 'aapúnm eesh '
húuk
áta
pa tá
kun 'uum .'"
s.trans: And he thought, "I'll find out where they've gone, all right."

s.txt:
kári
xás
u patánvish
pa mukun 'eenishrúp ak .
s.trans: So he asked their front porch.

s.txt:
púxay
vúra xay
aapúnmu tih ara .
s.trans: (But) it didn't know.

s.txt:
káan
kúna
pa mukun 'aktinakír ak
vaa
káru
vúra
pu 'aapúnmu tih ara .
s.trans: The grasping stones there (at the doorway) didn't know either.

s.txt:
kári
xás
chavúra
u kôoha .
s.trans: And finally he stopped.

s.txt:
ikmaháchraam
kúuk
u 'íipma .
s.trans: He went back to the sweathouse.

s.txt:
chavúra
itahar éekxaram
tá
pu 'ikviit-hí tih ara
pá xuus
u 'íruvoo ti
pa mu hrôoh as .
s.trans: Finally he didn't sleep for ten nights, as he thought about his wives.

s.txt:
kári
xás
mu kmaháchraam
tárupak
káan
u p ikrîish .
s.trans: And he sat down there at his sweathouse, in the hatchway.

s.txt:
vúra
kích
u kupi tih ,
xuus
u 'íruvoo ti .
s.trans: He did only (this), he thought about them.

s.txt:
chavúra
teepshítaanivanihich
axmáy
vaa
u kúupha ,
sâam
u tfáku tih .
s.trans: Finally after a while suddenly he did this, he looked downhill.

s.txt:
axmáy
ára
u 'árih raa .
s.trans: Suddenly a person came up.

s.txt:
xás
u xú ti "
ikxaréeyav
u 'árih raa ."
s.trans: And he thought, "A spirit is coming up."

s.txt:
yánava
uum
káru
vaa
u kupi ti
pá 'uum
u kupi ti
ikmahachram'íshiip veekxaréeyav .
s.trans: He saw that (the other person) was also doing what Sacred Sweathouse Spirit was doing.

s.txt:
víkapu
u skúruh ti .
s.trans: (Namely:) He was carrying a quiver.
s.note: Bright writes "Namely:" before sentence 43, but, although it has no equivalent in the Karuk, he does not put it in parentheses.

s.txt:
yánava
uum
káru
vaa
u kupi tih ,
víkapu
u skúruh tih .
s.trans: He saw he was doing that too, he was carrying a quiver.

s.txt:
chavúra
kaanvári
u 'uum .
s.trans: Finally (the person) arrived there.

s.txt:
ta'ítam
kun 'uhyániichva .
s.trans: Then they chatted.

s.txt:
xás
kun ípeen ti
ikmahachram'íshiip veekxaréeyav "
hûut
kích
i xú tih ."
s.trans: And (the person) said to Sacred Sweathouse Spirit, "How are you feeling?"

s.txt:
xás
u piip , "
vúra
kâarim
pa ni xú tih .
s.trans: And he said, "I'm feeling bad.

s.txt:
yukún
nani hrôoh as
húukava
tá
kun 'uum ."
s.trans: You see, my wives have gone somewhere."

s.txt:
xás
u piip , "
ník
vaa
ni xú ti '
t ée
kúupha .'"
s.trans: And (the other) said, "I know you are doing that."

s.txt:
kári
xás
u piip , "
naa
ni 'aapúnmu ti '
pa mi hrôov as
hôoy
kun 'iin .'"
s.trans: And he said, "I know where your wives are."

s.txt:
xás
u piip , "
naa
vaa
ni kupí tih .
s.trans: And he said, "I do this.

s.txt:
páy
p eethívthaaneen
thaanêen
ni p thivrúh iroopith vu tih .
s.trans: I float around and around this world.

s.txt:
víri
kôokaninay
ni 'aapúnmu ti
p eekxaréeyav
t u 'íifship .
s.trans: I know everyplace that a spirit has grown up.

s.txt:
yúruk
ithyáruk
víri
káan
kun 'íin
pa mi hrôoh as .
s.trans: Your wives are there on the other side of the ocean.

s.txt:
yúruk
ithyáruk
káan
xás
kun 'iru várupm anik .
s.trans: They arrived downriver there to the other side of the ocean.

s.txt:
víri
káan
xasík
í pmaah vunaa vish .
s.trans: You will find them again there.

s.txt:
máh'iit
pa yáan
t u súpaahi ti
vaa
kári
kun víik tih .
s.trans: In the morning, when it is just dawn, they are weaving.

s.txt:
îikam
tá
kun p iru kûurish ,
yukún
vaa
kun kupi tih ,
fúrax
mukun pikshipíkmath .
s.trans: They sit down again outdoors; you see, they do this; their sun-shades are of woodpecker heads.

s.txt:
víri va
káan
í pmaah vunaa vish
pa mi hrôoh as ."
s.trans: There you will find your wives again."

s.txt:
kári
xás
u xus ,
ikmahachram'íshiip veekxaréeyav , "
púya
chími
ikxáramh i ."
s.trans: Then Sacred Sweathouse Spirit thought, "Well, let it get dark!"

s.txt:
xás
vúra
pu 'ikviit-h ára .
s.trans: And he didn't sleep.

s.txt:
p eekxarám'aachip
t u vâamyuv ,
xás
u xus , "
chími
kan vâaram i ."
s.trans: When midnight had passed, then he thought, "Let me go!"

s.txt:
kári
xás
mu taxyêem ak
káan
xás
u hyárihish .
s.trans: Then he stood still there in his yard.

s.txt:
xás
vaa
u kúupha ,
xánahich
vúra
u xapyuxúyux .
s.trans: And he did this, he rubbed his foot in the dirt for a little while.

s.txt:
ta'ítam
u taxáraapsipree vish .
s.trans: He was about to take a stride.

s.txt:
yúruk
kuma yurás viitkir
káan
xás
u taxarápish .
s.trans: Then he ended his stride downriver there, on some ocean ridge.

s.txt:
ta'ítam
u krîishrih een .
s.trans: So he sat down.

s.txt:
yánava
tá
vúra
hári va
tá
kun p iru kûurishrih een ,
tá
kun ip vík aheen .
s.trans: He saw they had sat down again sometime, they were weaving again.

s.txt:
xás
yûuth
u trûupu tih .
s.trans: Then he looked down across.

s.txt:
kári
xás
u xus , "
chími
kan fúmtaapsur ."
s.trans: And he thought, "Let me blow."

s.txt:
xás
p oo fúmtaapsur
víri
yûuth
p oo trûupu tih ,
xánahich
axmáy
vaa
u kuupha ,
pa mukun furax pikshipíkmath
axmáy
u 'áapuchur .
s.trans: And when he blew, as he looked down across, in a little while suddenly they did this, (the women's) woodpecker-head sun-shades suddenly collapsed.

s.txt:
víri
vaa
u kuupha ,
chaka'îich
kúnish
kun 'ixipúniih va .
s.trans: They did that, they sort of floated slowly down.

s.txt:
xás
u xús "
vaa
ník
chími
kan ipvâaram ."
s.trans: And he thought, "Let me go back home!"

s.txt:
xás
u xus , "
kaanvári
ni p taxarápishrih eesh
nani taxyêem ak ."
s.trans: And he thought, "I'll stride back there into my yard."

s.txt:
kári
xás
vaa
u kuupha ,
xánahich
u xapyuxúyux .
s.trans: And he did this, he rubbed his foot in the dirt for a little while.
s.note: Bright does not write a length mark after the u in kuupha, but there is a space there where the length dot would have been and that vowel is expected to be long.

s.txt:
ta'ítam
u taxáraapsipree vish .
s.trans: So he was about to stride.

s.txt:
víri
chími
u p taxáraapsipree vish ,
táma
takráav
xákarari
kun p íkuuyva
pa mu hrôoh as .
s.trans: He was about to stride back, (when) his wives landed on his shoulders on either side.

s.txt:
ta'ítam
u taxáraapsipree vish .
s.trans: So he was about to stride.

s.txt:
mu taxyêem ak
u taxáraapramnih .
s.trans: He strode into his yard.

s.txt:
ta'ítam
iinâak
u p oonvá furuk
pa mu hrôoh as
ikmahachram'íshiip .
s.trans: So he took his wives back into the sacred sweathouse.

s.txt:
kári
xás
u xús aanik
ikmahachram'íshiip veekxaréeyav , "
yaas'ara 'îin
ta na 'apúnmiik ahaak ,
yaas'ára
káru
vaa
u kuph eesh ."
s.trans: And Sacred Sweathouse Spirit thought, "If Mankind has learned it from me, Mankind will do so too."
s.note: Bright doesn't write a vowel length dot in ikmahachram'íshiip, but there is a space there and that vowel is expected to be long. Bright unexpectedly writes ta as one word with the verb na'apúnmiikahaak and also writes it unaccented. Because he doesn't accent it, I have left it written with the verb. (If he had meant it to be written separate, it probably would have a separate accent)

s.txt:
víri
naa
kích
îim
ikmahachram'íshiip veekxaréeyav .
s.trans: Only I have learned it from you, Sacred Sweathouse Spirit.
s.note: There is nothing corresponding to "have learned it from" in the Karuk. îim must be 2sg, but it shouldn't have circumflex accent (I don't think it could be îim meaning 'outdoors').

s.txt:
víri
naa
káru
vaa
ni kuph eesh .
s.trans: I will do so too.
